summary: admissions diagnoses included pneumonia (480–486), upper respiratory infection (465), bronchitis (466), influenza (487), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (490 to 492; 496), asthma (493), viral illness (079.9), dyspnea (786), acute respiratory failure (518.81), pneumonitis due to solids/liquids (507), or fever (780.6) the assay was specific and did not react with coronavirus, influenza A or B, human metapneumovirus, parainfluenzavirus, respiratory syncytial virus, or rhinovirus. the real-time RT-PCR assay was validated against a panel of influenza C clinical isolates. two of the 13 samples had another virus codetected along with influenza C. one patient was coinfected with influenza A and another was coinfected with respiratory syncytial virus. no codetection with human metapneumovirus was found. influenza C was not detected in 2 of the 6 seasons (2007–2008 and 2011–2012), whereas 5 of the 13 cases occurred in 2010–11. influenza C was not detected in 2 of the 6 seasons (2007–2008 and 2011–2012), whereas 5 of the 13 cases occurred in 2010–11. influenza C was detected in 7 (0.42%) patients ages 18 to 49 years of age. influenza was an uncommon cause of either outpatient visits or hospitalizations in adults.
